text: John, chapter number one, and get used to the book of First John will be here on Sunday mornings throughout the year. And I have read the book of First John over the last 60 days, about 60 times, and not just exclusively for my Bible reading, just in addition to my Bible reading to really get the entirety of this book into my mind. As you know, each year I choose a theme for our church, an annual church theme, and I seek direction from the Lord and ask to have guidance and wisdom with regard to the particular theme for that year. And each year since I've been here, I've had a theme, and I've enjoyed the opportunity to kind of keep on track with a theme, keep it before us, and keep a theme song, notes of not only bookmarks, but sermon notebooks, calendars, just all of it, and just really keep the theme before us. And it helps me. I trust that it helps you as well. In 2012, the first full calendar year that I was here, we looked at a theme. I titled it Standing on His Promises. And of course, we find that there are wonderful promises in the Word of God. Peter described them as exceeding great and precious promises, and we went through a whole host of promises from the Word of God, and we dealt with the fact that there are some promises that are unconditional. And we looked at the conditional, unconditional promises. In 2013, I preached through the book of Esther. Our theme was For Such a Time as This, and I greatly enjoyed the book of Esther. What does that mean? It's the only one, right? It's not my opinion, it's not your opinion, it's not what the church fathers said, it's what God says. We're going to agree with each other, right? Because God's Word is the standard and it is the authority. And so as I'm walking in the light, to walk in the light, remember it reveals obedience, yes, the progress, but as I'm walking in the light, and I'm having that fellowship with God, it also means that I have fellowship one with another. Maybe you're going to walk with your spouse, and you're making progress, you're taking a walk and physically speaking, and you have communion one with another, you have fellowship one with another. As we walk with God, we have fellowship with God, but as collectively, so as individuals we have fellowship with God, but then collectively or corporately when we're all walking in the light, we then have fellowship not only with God, but then one with another. And it's sweet, and what joy to have that fellowship one with another. Very very challenging and very difficult when you're not with one another. And so this year, in 2022, we'll study through the book of first John, I believe that, man, we'll be encouraged through the truth of 1 John. God wants us to know some things. He wants us to be settled on some things. He doesn't want us to be tossed to and fro with every wind of doctrine. He wants us to be settled, to know, and the word is used over and over and over. He wants us to know. You know what He wants us to know the most? He wants us to know that we belong to Him. 1 John 5.13 is probably one of the most commonly memorized verses of all of 1 John. These things have I written unto you that believe on the name of the Son of God, that ye may know that ye have eternal life.
